I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  a  proposed 
multitranche  financing  facility  (MFF)  to  Mongolia  for  the  Urban  Transport  Development 
Investment Program.1 
 
2. 
The program targets investments in urban transport and related urban transport services 
in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. This will improve connectivity; reduce traffic congestion; 
and promote sustainable, safe, reliable, and efficient transport.2 
 

II. 

THE INVESTMENT PROGRAM 

Rationale 

A. 
 
3. 
The  population  of  Ulaanbaatar  has  been  growing  rapidly.  The  city  grew  from  about 
600,000  people  in  1989  to  over  1.2  million  in  2010,  representing  42.8%  of  the  nation’s 
population  (2.8  million).  Migration  to  Ulaanbaatar  is  expected  to  continue  in  the  future  —it  is 
estimated that the population of the city will reach 1.4 million in 2020 and 1.7 million in 2030.3 
Development  of  sustainable  urban  transport  for  the  growing  population  is  one  of  the  most 
important urban development issues facing the city. 
 
Since 2000, the number of registered vehicles has increased by 4.4 times.4 An average 
4. 
of 35,000 private vehicles has been added annually, representing an average increase of more 
than  25%  per  year.  The  increasing  number  of  vehicles,  unplanned  urbanization,  the 
overburdened  transport  system,  and  poor  traffic  management  are  contributing  to  congestion, 
reduced traffic safety, and deteriorating air quality. Although the total number of recorded traffic 
accidents  has  been  falling  after  peaking  in  2000,5 the  number  of  traffic  fatalities  and  personal 
injury  accidents  relative  to  the  number  of  registered  vehicles  remains  alarming.  An  annual 
incidence of 7.5 deaths per 10,000 vehicles highlights the need for continued improvements in 
urban road safety and better protection for pedestrians. 
 
5. 
Increased trip frequency and travel time, excessive fuel use, and high vehicle emissions 
are reducing the quality of life and causing health problems in Ulaanbaatar. Although there has 
been  a  rapid  increase  in  motor  vehicles,  the  majority  of  Ulaanbaatar  residents  rely  on  public 
transport  or  walking.  The  congestion  on  the  city’s  roads  has  reduced  the  speed,  quality,  and 
reliability of bus services. These problems are particularly acute for the poor because they face 
longer travel distances and higher costs, ride in overcrowded and poorly maintained buses, and 
are most affected by the lack of infrastructure provision for pedestrians. 
 
6. 
Ulaanbaatar needs significant investment in its public transport system to ensure access 
to economic opportunities and social services for all its residents, and to support inclusive and 
sustainable  economic  growth.  There  has  been  chronic  underinvestment  in  public  transport,

over 70% of annual traffic accidents in the country. 

 

 2 

 

which  has  not  kept  pace  with  recent  urban  growth.  The  majority  of  buses  are  more  than  10 
years  old  and  in  poor  condition.  Large  parts  of  the  trolleybus  infrastructure  are  no  longer 
functioning due to lack of maintenance, and service quality is deteriorating. About 40% of public 
transport passengers are subsidized by the municipal budget, but the mechanism for allocating 
subsidies  to  bus  operators  lacks  transparency  and  is  perceived  as  inequitable.  Most  bus 
operators  lack  the  financial  resources  to  renew  and  expand  their  bus  fleets  and  provide  an 
adequate level of service. 
 
The road network in Ulaanbaatar has not been expanded to accommodate the increased 
7. 
population  and  vehicles.  From  1990  to  2006,  only  two  road  construction  projects  were  carried 
out,  both  financed  by  bilateral  donor  agencies.  Between  2007  and  2011,  only  42.5  kilometers 
(km) of new roads were constructed and 68 km of existing roads were rehabilitated. About 65% 
of Ulaanbaatar’s road network is in poor condition. The road network is particularly deficient in 
the  outlying  residential  areas,  where  over  700,000  people  live  (around  60%  of  the  city’s 
population), including most low-income families. The lack of a reliable road network is a major 
barrier to the provision of public transport to serve these areas. 
 
8. 
The  municipality  of  Ulaanbaatar  (MUB)  city  master  plan  aims  to  develop  the  city’s 
infrastructure,  including  its  urban  roads,  utility  network,  and  transport  system.  The  MUB  road 
fund  finances  road  network  construction  and maintenance  works,  but  it  is  insufficient  to  cover 
the  city’s  needs.  Although  experienced  in  managing  the  existing  urban  transport  system,  the 
MUB  needs  to  strengthen  its  capacity  to  (i)  develop,  implement,  and  enforce  urban  transport 
policy  and  strategy;  (ii)  undertake  long-term  investment  planning,  capital  budgeting,  and 
financial  management;  and  (iii)  design  and  manage  urban  transport  projects  financed  by 
international development partners. 
 
9. 
To  address  these  challenges,  Ulaanbaatar  requires  a  comprehensive  program  to 
improve  its  urban  transport  system.  This  includes  investments  in  infrastructure  combined  with 
modern  traffic  management  technologies,  policy  reforms,  efficient  and  sustainable  public 
transport services, and institutional development. 
 
10. 
Development  partner  coordination.  International  development  partners  have  played 
an  important  role  in  supporting  urban  transport  development  in  Mongolia.  In  preparing  the 
investment program, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) has coordinated closely with each of 
these  partners  to  (i)  ensure  synergies  with  existing  and  planned  international  support,  and  (ii) 
contribute  to  policy  dialogue  with  the  Government  of  Mongolia  on  introducing  a  financially 
sustainable  and  environmentally  friendly  transport  system  to  support  inclusive  economic 
growth.6 
 
11. 
Sector experience. Past transport projects in Mongolia have experienced cost overruns 
and implementation delays. ADB has taken steps to prevent cost overruns under the investment 
program  through  extensive  due  diligence  of  the  cost  estimates.  All  estimates  are  based  on 
recent  bid  prices  from  recent  projects  implemented  by  the  MUB.  Past  implementation  delays 
were caused by problems with preparing bid documents, bid evaluation reports, and acceptable 
withdrawal  applications,  and  with  evaluating  bids.  ADB  intends  to  address  the  implementation 
problems  with  a  multifaceted  capacity  development  effort  that  will  provide  international 
consultancy support to the MUB. This will directly assist with, and provide on-the-job training in, 
every  aspect  of procurement,  project management,  and  implementation for  the  duration  of the 
first tranche implementation period. 

                                                
6  Development Coordination (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 

 

 Justification for financing modality. An MFF is proposed as the financing modality for 
12. 
the  investment  program.  Ulaanbaatar’s  urban  infrastructure  is  growing  very  rapidly  and  urban 
transport requires a range of complementary investments over the next decade. The investment 
program will enable ADB to provide the medium- to long-term commitment that the government 
needs  to  improve  the  city’s  urban  transport  system.  The  expected  cost  of  the  required 
investments  is  about  $274.4  million,  which  is  significantly  more  than  ADB  has  been  able  to 
provide under a single loan to Mongolia. The MFF modality allows ADB to include the full scope 
of the urban transport sector improvement under the investment program. It also enables ADB 
to sequence its financing in relation to the MUB’s ability to implement the investment program. 
 
13.  Multitranche  financing  facility  constituents:  Sector  road  map  and  policy 
framework.  ADB  has  had  extensive  dialogue  with  the  government  to  formulate  a  sector  road 
map  and  capacity  development  program.  This  road  map  establishes  medium-  and  long-term 
performance objectives for the urban transport sector of Ulaanbaatar and draws up a series of 
targets  and  actions  to  be  implemented.  The  investment  program  will  strengthen  the  MUB’s 
institutional  and  implementation  capacity  and  help  it  implement  the  road  map,  policy  actions, 
and investment program. The road map implementation targets are incorporated as government 
undertakings for the MFF. 
 
Strategic  context.  The  investment  program  addresses  ADB’s  strategic  goals7 in  the 
14. 
urban  transport  sector:  (i)  promoting  clean,  efficient,  and  sustainable  urban  transport; 
(ii) improving  sector  institutions,  management,  human  capacity,  and  asset  sustainability;  and 
(iii) developing  and  improving  urban  transport  infrastructure  and  services.  The  investment 
program  objectives  are  fully  consistent  with  the  strategic  goals  of  the  country  partnership 
strategy8 and ADB's transport sector operational plan, the Sustainable Transport Initiative.9 
 
15. 
Investment  program.  The  investment  program  includes  (i) construction  of  bus  rapid 
transit  (BRT)  infrastructure  (roads,  bridges,  and  stations);  and  (ii)  development  of  a  BRT 
system,  including  a  bus  management  system  (BMS)  and  bus  information  system  (BIS). 
Nonphysical  components  include  institutional  capacity  development  in  the  urban  transport 
sector,  support  for  local  contractors,  extensive  on-the-job  training  in  project  management  and 
implementation, and sector reform initiatives adopted in the road map and policy framework to 
be  implemented  with  support  from  the  capacity  development  TA.  The  link  between  the  MFF 
physical investments and the sector road map implementation will provide strong incentives for 
sector development and reform. 
 
B. 
 
16. 
The  impact  of  the  investment  program  will  be  sustainable  economic  growth  of 
Ulaanbaatar promoted by a sustainable and efficient urban transport system and services. The 
outcome  will  be  development  of  efficient,  safe,  and  affordable  urban  transport  services  in 
Ulaanbaatar. 
 

Impact and Outcome

Outputs 

C. 
 
17. 
Project  1.  Outputs  to  be  financed  under  project  1  will  be  (i)  developing  BRT 
infrastructure  (improve  7.7 km  of road,  expand  the  Peace  Bridge for  the  BRT,  and  install  14.0 
km  of  electric  trolleybus  infrastructure  [electric  wires,  feeder  cables,  and  substations])  for  the 
BRT system in the north–south corridor of Ulaanbaatar; (ii)  introducing a 14.0 km BRT line on 
the  north–south  corridor,  and  procuring  five  trolleybuses  and  vehicle  emission  testing 
equipment;  (iii)  installing  an  intelligent  transport  system  (ITS)  component  (the  BMS);  and  (iv) 
providing resources for project management, detailed engineering design, and institutional  and 
policy development. In addition, ADB plans to prepare and provide TA to help the MUB develop 
a performance-based contract for BRT operation, and improve the public transport management 
capacity of the Public Transport Department. 
 
18. 
Project  2.  Outputs  to  be  financed  under  project  2  are  expected  to  be  (i)  further 
expanding the BRT infrastructure and services, including extending the BRT corridors (27.9 km) 
and  installing  trolleybus  infrastructure  (electric  wires,  feeder  cables,  and  substations)  in  the 
north–south, east–west, and ring road corridors (11.1 km), upgrading bus depots, and procuring 
BRT  buses  and  trolleybuses;  (ii)  implementing  traffic  management  and  pedestrian  safety 
programs,  which  will  include  improving  geometry  and  pedestrian  facilities  of  10  urban  road 
intersections;  (iii)  installing  ITS  components  (BIS  and  e-ticketing  system  [phase  1]);  and  (iv) 
providing  resources  for  institutional  development,  detailed  engineering  design,  and  project 
management. 
 
19. 
Project  3.  Outputs  to  be  financed  under  project  3  are  expected  to  be  (i)  further 
expanding the BRT infrastructure, including improving 4.6 km of urban road as required for the 
BRT  system  and  installing  trolleybus  infrastructure  (electric  wires,  feeder  cables,  and 
substations)  in  the  east–west  corridor;  (ii)  extending  the  BRT  system,  including  extending  the 
east–west BRT corridor (22.6 km), constructing BRT bus depots and a bus–rail intermodal hub, 
and procuring BRT buses and trolleybuses; (iii) expanding ITS components (BIS and e-ticketing 
system  [phase  2]);  and  (iv)  providing  resources  for  project  management,  detailed  engineering 
design, and institutional development. 
 
D. 
 
20. 
The  investment  program  will  help  the  MUB  develop  a  sustainable,  efficient,  affordable, 
and environmentally friendly transport system that will prioritize public transport and traffic and 
road  safety.  The  BRT,  as  the  core  of  the  public  transport  system,  will  be  underpinned  by 
infrastructure  improvement,  policy  reforms,  capacity  development,  and  introduction  of  modern 
ITS  technologies.  Introduction  of  the  BRT-dedicated  lines  will  significantly  reduce  passenger 
travel  time,  which  will  provide  more  time  for  productive  economic  activities  and  improve  the 
quality  of  life,  especially  for  low-income  residents.  Use  of  environmentally  friendly  buses  and 
trolleybuses,  combined  with  reduction  of  the  overall  bus  fleet  and  use  of  private  vehicles,  will 
reduce  vehicle  emissions  and  contribute  to  reducing  carbon  emissions.  The  ITS  components 
(BMS, BIS, and e-ticketing) will increase the efficiency and transparency of the public transport 
financial management and subsidy systems. 
 
E. 
 
The  investment  program  is  estimated  to  cost  $274.4  million  (Table  1).  Project  1, 
21. 
inclusive  of  taxes,  duties,  physical  and  price  contingencies,  interest,  and  other  charges,  is 
estimated to cost $78.4 million.

22. 
The government has requested an MFF in an amount up to $217.4 million from a blend 
of ADB's Special Funds resources, ordinary capital resources (OCR), and Global Environment 
Facility  (GEF)  grant  funding  to  help finance  a  part  of  the  investment  program.10 Mongolia  was 
reclassified as a group B country eligible for OCR financing on 16 August 2011.11 The MFF will 
consist  of  three  tranches,  subject  to  the  government  submitting  related  periodic  financing 
requests,  executing  the  related  loan  agreements  for  each  tranche,  and  fulfilling  the  terms  and 
conditions  and  undertakings  set  forth  in  the  framework  financing  agreement  (FFA).  The  first 
tranche, for $61.4 million equivalent, will be financed from the Asian Development Fund (ADF), 
OCR, and GEF. The ADF loan for $30.2 million equivalent will have a 32-year term, including a 
grace period of 8 years, an interest rate of 1.0% per annum during the grace period and 1.5% 
per  annum  thereafter,  and  such  other  terms  and  conditions  set  forth  in  the  relevant  loan 
agreement. The OCR loan for $29.7 million will have a 20-year term, including a 5-year grace 
period,  an  interest  rate  determined  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  London  interbank  offered  rate-
based  lending  facility,  a  commitment  charge  of  0.15%  per  year,  and  such  other  terms  and 
conditions as set forth in the relevant loan agreement.12 A grant for $1.5 million will be provided 
from the GEF fund. The government will provide counterpart funding to finance civil works, land 
acquisition, and resettlement, and exempt the project from taxes and duties. 
 
23. 
The  MFF  comprises  blend  financing  from  ADF,  OCR  and  cofinancing  up  to  the  MFF 
amount. Thus, the provision of any ADF resources is balanced by a corresponding reduction of

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

The  project  team  has  prepared  feasibility  assessments  of  project  1,  including  the  BRT 
29. 
infrastructure  and  system  development,  ITS,  traffic  management,  and  pedestrian  safety. 
Technical due diligence was performed for the investment program and included an assessment 
of  the  strategy  and  policy  framework,  road  map,  investment  program,  and  specific  investment 
proposals under the first tranche. The investment program is technically viable with technology 
choices based on efficient and proven designs. 
 
B. 

Economic and Financial 

30. 
The  economic  internal  rate  of  return  for  tranche  1  investments  was  calculated.  The 
economic  benefits  are  travel  time  and  vehicle  operating  costs  savings.  The  analysis  showed 
that  project  1  is  economically  viable,  with  an  economic  internal  rate  of  return  of  24.8%  at  a 
12.0%  discount  rate.  Sensitivity  analysis  confirmed  this  economic  viability.  The  sensitivity 
analysis considered project economic viability under various scenarios. Economic and financial 
analysis will be conducted for all future subprojects financed under the MFF.

C. 

Governance 

31. 
All works and goods to be financed under the MFF will be procured in accordance with 
ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines.  All  consulting  services  to  be  financed  under  the  MFF  will  be 
procured  in accordance with  ADB's  Guidelines  on  the  Use of  Consultants  (2010,  as  amended 
from  time  to  time).  ADB’s  Anticorruption  Policy  (1998,  as  amended  to  date)  was  explained  to 
and  discussed  with  the  government.  The  specific  policy  requirements  and  supplementary 
measures  are  described  in  the  facility  administration  manual  (footnote  15).  A  financial 
management  and  procurement  assessment  indicates  that  the  MUB’s  financial  management, 
reporting, procurement, and monitoring systems are satisfactory. 
 
D. 

Poverty and Social 

32. 
Project  1  will  directly  benefit  residents  along  the  BRT  corridors  and  indirectly  benefit 
about  1.2  million  urban  residents  by  improving  living  conditions  and  the  economic  and  urban 
environment in Ulaanbaatar. The potential beneficiaries are local residents, students, and road 
and public transport users. Businesses will benefit from greater people mobility and connectivity. 
The poor and socially excluded will benefit from (i) better access to the city’s activity centers, (ii) 
affordable  public  transport,  (iii)  better  living  conditions  and  less  pollution,  (iv)  employment 
opportunities,  and  (v)  development  of  business  activities  after  project  completion.  Project  1  is 
designed  as  effective  gender  mainstreaming.  The  gender  action  plan  for  the  investment 
program  will  ensure  equal  gender  access  to  urban  transport. 16 Poverty,  gender,  and  social 
assessments will be done in preparation for subsequent tranches to determine their respective 
categorization  and  required  actions.  The  BRT  will  include  gender-responsive  and  universal 
design features and focus on pedestrian safety; ease of access for the elderly, children, and the 
disabled; and public awareness. A parallel grant project focuses on road safety in school areas. 
 
E. 

Safeguards 

33. 
Environment.  To  comply  with  national  laws  and  ADB  requirements,  an  environmental 
assessment  and  review  framework  was  reviewed  by  ADB’s  Regional  and  Sustainable 
Development Department and the MUB. 17 Environment classification of project 1 is category B 
as it will not have significant irreversible or permanent negative environmental impacts during or 
after  construction.  To  comply  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009),  an  initial 
environmental examination was prepared and disclosed.18 The environmental management plan 
will become an integral part of construction contracts. Assuming effective implementation of the 
mitigation measures and monitoring requirements outlined in the plan, project 1 is not expected 
to  have  significant  adverse  environmental  impacts.  Subsequent  projects  are  expected  to  be 
classified environment category B.
